title-group.article-title: A Novel Concealed Information Test Method Based on Independent Component Analysis and Support Vector Machine

abstract.p: The concealed information test (CIT) has drawn much attention and has been widely investigated in recent years. In this study, a novel CIT method based on denoised P3 and machine learning was proposed to improve the accuracy of lie detection. Thirty participants were chosen as the guilty and innocent participants to perform the paradigms of 3 types of stimuli. The electroencephalogram (EEG) signals were recorded and separated into many single trials. In order to enhance the signal noise ratio (SNR) of P3 components, the independent component analysis (ICA) method was adopted to separate non-P3 components (ie, artifacts) from every single trial. In order to automatically identify the P3 independent components (ICs), a new method based on topography template was proposed to automatically identify the P3 ICs. Then the P3 waveforms with high SNR were reconstructed on Pz electrodes. Second, the 3 groups of features based on time,frequency, and wavelets were extracted from the reconstructed P3 waveforms. Finally, 2 classes of feature samples were used to train a support vector machine (SVM) classifier because it has higher performance compared with several other classifiers. Meanwhile, the optimal number of P3 ICs and some other parameter values in the classifiers were determined by the cross-validation procedures. The presented method achieved a balance test accuracy of 84.29% on detecting P3 components for the guilty and innocent participants. The presented method improves the efficiency of CIT in comparison with previous reported methods.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, many researchers have investigated CIT methods based on event-related potentials (ERPs). 1 –3 P300 (P3), an extensively studied endogenous ERP, is a response to rare, meaningful stimuli often called “oddball” stimuli.4,5 It has been demonstrated that being a fast response of the central nervous system to the stimuli, it could hardly be inhibited by participants.6 It is a positive-going wave with a clear scalp distribution, in which the largest value is typically at the Pz electrode, smallest at Fz, taking intermediate value at Cz. When a crime has been committed, crime-related information would evoke the participant’s memory of the crime detail and then elicit a P3, which is not true for an innocent participant. Considering the features of P3, many researchers began to utilize this tool to do the CIT and had proved that P3 was sensitive to lie detection.4,5,7,8
Generally, 3 types of stimuli are presented to participants for the P3-based CIT:

list-item.p: Probe (P) stimuli, which are facts related to criminal acts. The guilty participant is certainly familiar with these stimuli, whereas for the innocent participant this is not the case.
Target (T) stimuli, which are known by all the participants but not related to the criminal acts.
Irrelevant (I) stimuli, which are not known by all the participants and not related to criminal acts.

sec.p: The current P3-based CIT methods include the bootstrapped amplitude difference (BAD), the bootstrapped correlation difference (BCD), 9 and the machine learning methods. 5 The BAD approach compares the amplitude of P3 responses in P and I stimuli. For guilty participants, one expects that the P3 amplitude in P stimuli is larger than that in I stimuli. By contrast, for the innocent participants no difference between P and I is expected. The BCD approach is based on the correlation theory. For a guilty participant, one expects that the cross correlation between P and T response is larger than that between P and I response, whereas for innocent participants there should be an opposite result.

For the P3-based CIT, both spontaneous EEG and background noises such as electrooculography (EOG) and electromyography (EMG) are seen as noise for extracting the P3 from the recorded EEG signals. The ERP is superimposed deeply on the ongoing EEG. 10 Thus, it is often difficult to observe or directly obtain an ERP in the recorded EEG signals. The BAD and BCD methods in fact apply the average method, that is, coherent averaging technique, to reduce the noise in the EEG. The assumption of coherent averaging technique, that P3 response has the time-phase locked relation to the stimuli, could not have been strictly satisfied. On the contrary, spontaneous EEG and other noise would sometimes be related to the stimuli. Thus, this averaging technique could not eliminate the noise in EEG and then extract the P3 from EEG perfectly. 10 More importantly, the 2 methods (BAD and BCD) are absent from the analysis from trial to trial. They disregard the fact that in different epochs, ERP response may vary in time course or scalp distribution. This variation may reflect differences in the participant’s expectation, attention, arousal, and task strategy. 11,12 The analysis of single trials may potentially reveal much richer information about event-related brain dynamics. This information of dynamic variation may help an examiner to terminate the experiment or change the type of the stimuli during the lie detection, which is a flexible mode and thus favorable for the CIT.

Machine learning methods may become the better analysis tool for CIT. By machine learning methods, we could further investigate the wealth of information 10 about the dynamic variation of single trials such as the variation in the peak and latency of the P3. In addition, the pattern recognition approach is also more practical, because the classifier does not require being trained for the person who will participant in the test task. 13 However, current machine learning-based CIT methods run into another extreme. Commonly, the signals from electrodes were directly regarded as P3. Few of these methods took into account and dealt with the noise in the ERP. They extracted 2 classes of feature samples directly from the EEG signals (at the electrodes) to train the classifiers. All these methods, therefore, are not “response based” but “task based,” 14 and hence the classification accuracy would be affected by introducing those incorrect P3 responses.

The P3 cannot be represented by the signal from sensor directly. The described lie detection methods could not separate P3 components from the single-trial EEG because their time courses and scalp projections generally overlap. 15 In addition, these methods usually utilized 1 or a few electrodes to record the EEG signals. In fact, there is rich mutual information 16 between the multiple scalp electrodes since the EEG signals are mixed from spatially fixed, overlapping, but temporally distinct, brain or extra-brain networks by volume conduction. 10 Recently, many investigators have discussed and demonstrated the effect of applying independent component analysis (ICA) to spatially separate artifacts, stimulus-related P3, nonevent-related background EEG signals to different output components. 17,18 Its effectiveness mainly arises from 2 assumptions on the algorithm model. First, from the perspective of blind source separation (BSS), 19,20 EEG signals were considered as the mixture of neuronal and noisy sources. This assumption was essentially reasonable, because volume conduction was considered to be linear and instantaneous. 15 Second, the artifact activities were assumed to be fully independent of brain activity. The related results show that the reconstructed signals from decomposed components are more distinguishable than the “sensor signals.” 17,18

In this study, we took full advantage of the features of the ICA to decompose each EEG data set (single-trial) into an IC set and spatial map set. The spatial map was the so-called IC topography which represented the weights of the corresponding IC at each EEG sensor. The ICs can be categorized into task related (ie, ERP) and task unrelated (ie, the noise for P3-based CIT) components. In order to automatically identify the P3 ICs from each IC set, we propose a simple but effective method which is based on the template of the P3 IC topography. First, the high consistency of P3 IC topography, in different guilty participants and in different stimuli, was validated, and then a template of the P3 IC topography was calculated. Second, the spatial maps correlating highly to pre-selected template were selected, and their corresponding ICs were regarded as P3 ICs, by which the P3 (for the guilty) and non-P3 (for the innocent) waveforms with higher SNR were finally reconstructed at sensors.

In order to automatically identity and classify the truth tellers and liars, 3 groups of typical features of P3 were selected and extracted from the reconstructed P3 waveforms. These features were concatenated as a featured vector and fed into 3 kinds of typical classifiers for training and testing. By comparing the performance of different classifiers, the optimal classifier and training parameters (detailed in the Materials and Methods section) for CIT were determined. By comparing with the performance of classifiers without ICA, the advantages of the proposed method are also demonstrated in this article. sec.title: Materials and Protocol
sec.p: Thirty healthy participants (8 women), aged 20 to 27 (mean 24), were selected from the undergraduate and graduate students. After a complete description of this study, consent was obtained from each participant. We then seated each participant in the EEG recording chair and activated the computer and recording equipment. The EEG data were digitized at 500 Hz using Neuroscan Synamps with online low- and high-pass filters of 0.3 and 30.0 Hz on the following 12 channels: Fp1, Fp2, F3, Fz, F4, C3, Cz, C4, P3, Pz, P4, and Oz. The vertical EOG (VEOG) signal was recorded from the right eye (2.5 cm below and above the pupil); and the horizontal EOG (HEOG) signal was recorded from the outer canthus. An electrode on the right earlobe served as the reference. Participants were randomly divided into 2 groups: liar (LI) group and truth teller (TR) group. The standard 3 stimuli protocol14 was employed.

Before the experiment, 6 watches and their images were prepared. A box containing 2 watches was given to the guilty participants. They were instructed to open the box and performed a mock crime scenario5 after we left the room. Among the 6 images, the stolen one was P stimulus, the other one in the box was T stimulus, the remaining images were I stimuli. For the TR group, they only saw 1 watch in the box (ie, T stimulus in the box) and stole nothing. Thus, 1 of the remaining 5 images was randomly appointed as P stimulus by us. The images of the watches were then randomly presented at the screen. Each of them lasted 1.2 seconds with 30 iterations for 1 session. All the participants replied honestly to T and I stimuli by pressing the “Yes” or “No” button in their hand. When the P stimulus appeared, the guilty participant was instructed to push the “No” button (ie, lying) and the innocent participant pushed the “No” button (ie, truth telling). Each session lasted about 5 minutes with a 2-minute interval. Each participant was instructed to perform the 5 sessions discussed above. In each session, the presented probabilities of P, T, and I stimuli were 0.17 (30 times), 0.17 (30 times), and 0.66 (30 times for each I stimulus), respectively.

sec.title: Preprocessing
sec.p: Prior to the analysis, the seriously artifact-affected EEG data were rejected by visual inspection. Then the EEG data were first corrected for ocular artifacts based on VEOG and HEOG using the program contained by Neuroscan system. Then, the EEGLAB toolbox 21 was used to divide EEG data into many 1.6second (0.5 seconds pre-stimulus to 1.1 seconds post-stimulus) data sets (each set was a 14 × 800 matrix), and then the sets corresponding to P stimuli were selected. Thus, for each group, 2250 epoched sets (15 participants, 5 sessions for every participant, and 30 P stimuli for each session) were obtained. Each set was then baseline corrected on the pre-stimulus waves of each channel. Finally, 4500 EEG sets were obtained, among which 2250 epochs belonging to the LI group, R1, the first set, the others the TR group, R2, the second set.

sec.title: Topography template matching method
sec.p: After the EEG signals have been decomposed by ICA, the remaining crucial task is to automatically identify P3 ICs from the IC set. Many researchers reported various techniques to solve this problem. 17,26 However, most of them are complex. In this article, we proposed a topography template matching (TTM) method to reconstruct P3 waveforms with higher SNR. There have been many demonstrations that P3 is generally largest at Pz. Based on these related results, our TTM method is described as follows.

Based on the R1 set, average each 15 EEG sets within each liar, yielding 10 averaged EEG sets for each liar. ICA was run on each averaged EEG set. Of the 14 resulting topographies of the ICs, select only typical 1 for which the maximum project value is just on or centered in the Pz site, and the IC associated with the selected topography was regarded as P3 IC. Thus, 10 P3 IC topographies and corresponding ICs were obtained for each liar.

Recently, the wavelet transform (WT) has been widely used to analyze ERPs, 27 in which long time window is applied to analyze the lower-frequency component and short for high, which is called multiresolution decomposition. In this study, a fast algorithm for the discrete WT (DWT) 28 was adopted to decompose those reconstructed waveforms in R-G or R-I. Quadratic B-Spline functions 29 were selected as mother wavelets. The DWT was performed on each waveform with t varying from 500 to 1600 ms, resulting in 7 sets of wavelet coefficients corresponding to different frequency bands: 0.3 to 3.9, 3.9 to 7.8, 7.8 to 15.6, and 15.6 to 31.2. The coefficient set corresponding to the first frequency band was selected as the final wavelet features.

By the feature extraction procedure discussed above, each time series in the set R-G or R-I was transformed into a 32-dimensional feature vector which was classified as 2 sample sets according to whether the participant is a liar or a truth teller. We then used a subject wise CV (SWCV) 30 procedure on the 2 sample sets. For each set, samples from 14 participants were used as the training set and the samples from the remaining one were used as the test set. The generalization performance of a trained classifier was then evaluated using the test data. Thus, 15 pairs of training sets and test sets were obtained by this SWCV procedure. The training data were used to train a classifier with the different values of training parameters m and the parameters in classifier. Each training set was further subdivided into a sub-training set and a subtest set by a normal 10-fold CV procedure, 31 by which the optimal training parameter values could be obtained when the averaged test accuracy across the 10 test results on 10 subtest sets, was the highest. On the completion of each training procedure, the optimal parameters values were determined, the samples from a guilty participant and an innocent participant were tested, respectively, resulting in 2 test results: one is sensitivity and the other is specificity. 32 By SWCV procedure, we can obtain 15 pairs of sensitivity and specificity.

To select an optimal classifier, the performances of Fisher linear discriminant analysis (FDA), back propagation neural network (BPNN), and support vector machine (SVM) 20 were compared in this study. The BPNN consisted of an input layer, a hidden layer, and an output layer. The number of hidden nodes was decided by the training procedure. The goal of SVM was to find an optimal hyperplane that maximizes the separating margin between 2 classes of samples. By an appropriate nonlinear mapping (using kernel functions) of an input vector into a high-dimensional feature space, the data from 2 categories were separated via a hyperspace. For SVM, different kernel functions and the corresponding function parameters needed to be trained.

sec.title: Preprocessing
sec.p: The average ERPs at Fz, Cz, Pz, and Oz sites as a function of stimulus type were first calculated within each participant. Figure 2 shows this result for 1 LI and 1 TR. Observing the results at the third row, for the LI (left column), the response to the P stimuli was similar to that to T stimuli, differing significantly from that to I stimuli. In contrast, for the TR (right column), there was a great difference between the responses to P and T stimuli. Furthermore, we can see that for the LI, the amplitude in response to the P stimulus reaches the maximum at the Pz electrode, whereas for the TR, the amplitude in response to the P stimulus reaches a very low value at the Pz electrode. Hence, the responses to P stimuli at the Pz site were used to do further analysis in order to enhance the feature difference in the P3 waves between 2 kinds of participants.

sec.title: Topography template matching
sec.p: Figure 3A and B shows the analysis results of the P3 IC topography. Our result is based on only 1 LI who was randomly selected from the LI group due to space constraint, and the remaining ones were similar. The topography corresponding to the 10th IC was selected as the P3 IC topography due to the fact that the IC had the maximum distribution strength at Pz site (Figure 3). Figure 3B shows 10 P3 topographies for this participant. As shown in this figure, they all have the very similar pattern of the P3 IC topography. Figure 3C shows the final topography template of P3 IC, which was averaged across the 15 averaged P3 topographies from the 15 liars.

sec.p: The similarity values were calculated between the template and all decomposed topographies based on equation 3. For each epoched EEG data set, the maximum similarity value was picked. Thus, the 2 groups of similarity values were obtained. One group was for the liar, and the other one was for the truth teller. The means of the similarity with their corresponding standard deviations (SDs) of the 2 groups are shown in Figure 3D. From this figure, we can see that the mean of the LI group is significantly higher than that of the TR group. The similarity for LI group (SD = 0.121) has smaller variability than that of the TR group (SD = 0.278). This indicates that P3 IC topography has a very similar pattern compared with the topography of non-P3 IC.

sec.title: Classification
sec.p: The SWCV procedure was first performed on the 2 feature sets. Using the training set to train the 3 classifiers with different m, we could obtain the optimal value of m, classifier parameter values, sensitivity, and specificity based on 10-fold CV. These accuracies are shown in Table 1 (the numbers in parentheses). Second, the trained classifier was used to test the samples of a LI and a TR, thus resulting in the sensitivity and specificity of the LI and TR, respectively. These testing accuracies (the numbers outside parenthesis) are also illustrated in Table 1. We emphasize the importance of the SWCV procedure. In fact, a statistical classification model that could explain the data for some participants did not necessarily generalize well to other participants, even if those were draw from the same distribution. Accordingly, the SWCV procedure was used to assess the generalization ability not only from the different data within 1 participant but from the data within different participants.

sec.p: We can see from Table 1 that the accuracy rates of FDA are very low compared with the performance of BPNN and SVM. From this table, it can be noted that the accuracy rates of all these classifiers increase significantly when m increases from 1 to 2; and especially for the SVM, the increased rate is about 5%. The accuracy for BPNN is increasing slightly when m = 3. When more than 4 ICs are used, the accuracy rates become relatively lower. This result is basically consistent with the report of Lin et al. 18 For each classifier, those values are distinctly lower than the rates in the second row (i.e., m = 2). Based on the above results, the reconstructed coefficient m was set as 2. In addition, note that the rates in the bottom row denote the performance without ICA. Based on these results, the improved classification accuracy supports using ICA to enhance the SNR of P3.

From Table 1, it is noted that SVM outperforms FDA and BPNN significantly in terms of its greater classification accuracy. Predictive power, that is, generalization ability when making a decision from the responses of participants who did not participate in the training procedure, is also very high for SVM (since it has high test accuracy). Furthermore, we used analysis of variance (ANOVA) to determine the significance level of the difference in accuracy between SVM and BPNN. Analysis reveals that it is significantly greater for the SVM (F (1, 28) = 5388.145, P < .001). The balance test accuracy of 84.29% (for testing set) strongly suggests that applying SVM to classify the samples from 2 kinds of participants is reasonable.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The main purpose of this study was to propose and evaluate a novel CIT method based on P3 with higher SNR and the machine learning method. Thirty participants were involved in the experiment with the standard 3 stimuli protocol. Based on the widely used ICA, we proposed a denoising technique, TMM method, to select a P3 IC from the decomposed ICs, and then reconstruct the P3 waveforms at the Pz site. Experimental results show that this denoising technique can enhance the SNR of the P3, and hence improve the performance of distinguishing lying from telling the truth.

The presented method was not only highly effective but more practical for the testing personnel. All of the ERP-based CIT method should explain the SNR of the single trial being much lower. Coherent average technique was applied to reduce the noise for the BAD and BCD methods. However, these methods did not have the analysis from trial to trial. Hence, machine learning methods may have become the alternative tool. The main premise of this article has been that this novel CIT method can provide a trade-off between higher SNR of P3 and the analysis of single trial. Hence, we could research the wealth of dynamic variation information between the single trials. Based on the observed results of dynamic variation of single trials such as peak or latency of P3 waveforms, we could change the original stimuli content or sequence.

Previously reported methods still had their inherent drawbacks. They could not decide a participant’s status (liar or truth teller) until many stimuli were presented to the participant. 13 However, it does not exist in our method. We did not necessarily present many stimuli to the participant since no threshold selection problem was involved. In fact, many repeated stimuli with little information would induce 2 problems: fatigue from the participants and the increase of the countermeasures 8 especially when the real criminals were familiar with the stimuli contents, and hence tend to resist the detection on purpose. A lie detection method with only a small number of stimuli, in our view, will be crucial to extend the laboratory study to practical application.

The experimental results also demonstrate that a high-dimensionality nonlinear pattern classification method using kernel function, SVM, is able to detect the complex patterns of brain activities relevant to the deception. The SVM classifier learns by finding optimal hyperplane that separates feature points of 2 different classes in the feature space. This might not be the case in the NN, determination of an optimum separation hyperplane is not guaranteed since the training is not completely controlled by us. Finally, the balanced accuracy of 84.29% was obtained using the SVM classifier, indicating that we could implement a practical, efficient, low-fatigue, little countermeasure behavior CIT method.

In addition, based on the result of balanced accuracy of 84.29%, if choosing accuracy of 80% as a detecting standard of P3 component to classify a participant’s status (guilty or innocent), our method could achieve an individual diagnostic rate of 100%. Abootalebi et al 5 reported that the best detection rates were 74%, 80%, and 79% for BAD, BCD, and the machine learning methods, respectively. The individual diagnostic rate of our method was higher than the results of the other related reports.
